awd_titl_txt: Mid-Scale RI-1(M1:DP): Next Generation Radar Designs
awd_abstract_narration:
Associated Universities Inc. (AUI), the manager of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) and Green Bank Observatory (GBO) for NSF, and Raytheon Technologies, Inc. will partner on an integrated technical design for important new scientific and space domain awareness radar capabilities for the United States.  They will develop detailed conceptual designs for (a) a high-power high frequency phased-array radar transmitter for the Green Bank Telescope (GBT), and (b) a medium-power phased-array modular transmitter system for deployment on antennas under design for the next-generation Very Large Array (ngVLA) and other radar-capable facilities.  Successful designs are intended for use by these and other more speculative activities still to be defined.  The project includes a focus on broadening participation by under-represented minorities (URM) and the public in radar astronomy and related STEM fields.  It includes research and training experiences for URM students, middle and high school science lesson plans, and multimedia public outreach materials.

High-power radar observations provide unique information about natural solar system objects, including planets, near-Earth asteroids and other nearby objects, and about human activities in space, including spacecraft structure, performance and navigation, both nearby and beyond Earth.  New technical directions and operational approaches have been presented to the current Planetary Science and Astrobiology Decadal Survey for discussion.  They include more powerful transmitters, flexible phased-array transmit hardware, and antenna arrays as transmitters and receivers, and they all promise increased sensitivity and better operational readiness.  The design work between NSF’s NRAO and GBO, and Raytheon, their industrial collaborator, is an essential first step to a transformative future across multiple disciplines.  These technologies will drive advances in planetary defense, technology transfer and commercialization, and benefits for local communities surrounding observing facilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) and Green Bank Observatory (GBO), managed by Associated Universities, Inc. (AUI) on behalf of the National Science Foundation (NSF), partnered with Raytheon to develop a conceptual design for a next generation planetary radar system, otherwise known as ngRadar.  The design includes a high-power (500 kW), high-frequency (13.7 GHz; Ku band), wide-bandwidth (up to 600 MHz), solid-state, phased-array transmitter mounted on the NSF's 100-meter-diameter Green Bank Telescope (GBT) in West Virginia, along with its supporting infrastructure.  The design also includes the architecture for using the ten 25-meter-diameter antennas of the NSF's Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) to receive the transmitted signal once it echoes off its target.  The project culminated with the passing of the conceptual design review and successful deployments of a pilot transmitter on the GBT with reception of the signals by the VLBA.  These proof-of-concept results include the highest-resolution images of the Moon ever taken from the ground.

The vision of the project was to design a capable radar system to make use of new technologies (i.e., solid-state power amplifiers), employ new observing techniques and analysis methods (i.e., an array of radar receivers with the VLBA), and open up cislunar space (between the geosynchronous belt and the Moon) to regular observation by using separate transmitter and receiver sites.  The vision was also to operate at a unique frequency (or wavelength) compared to other radar systems, such as the NSF's Arecibo Observatory and the NASA Goldstone Solar System Radar (GSSR), and to complement the capabilities of GSSR and replace some of those lost in the collapse of Arecibo.  The conceptual design is responsive to findings and recommendations in the recent decadal survey of the planetary-science research community and supports federal roadmaps for the continued study of near-Earth objects (asteroids and comets) and the exploration of cislunar space.

Data analysis from the deployments of the low-power (700 W), pilot transmitter demonstrated compelling results.  These included meter-scale imaging of the Moon from the ground to study geology and dynamics, the ability to detect, track, and characterize near-Earth objects for planetary defense as well as space debris for safety and security of space-based assets, and the potential for characterizing solid bodies across the Solar System for planetary science.  All results will extend to, and be improved by, the high-power, higher-sensitivity design.  The successful deployments also demonstrated the potential of the GBT and VLBA to work as a multi-component radar system and provided valuable lessons learned about the system architecture and end-to-end concept of operations needed for the high-power design.

Three technical interchange meetings were held between NRAO, GBO, and Raytheon in 2022, which led to selection of the transmitter frequency of 13.7 GHz (Ku band), the nominal transmitter position on the GBT, and general refinement of the conceptual design.  In March 2023, an internal conceptual design review was held, and the conceptual design for the high-power radar system was presented to a panel of subject-matter experts from NRAO and GBO.  The panel provided valuable insight for improving the design prior to external review. 

An external conceptual design review was held in November 2023.  The conceptual design for the radar system was presented to a panel of subject-matter experts from outside the project organizations, including universities, national laboratories, and federal facilities, with expertise ranging from astronomy and planetary science to various fields of engineering.  A final report was issued by the panelists, passing the conceptual design through to the next phase of development and providing comments outlining potential design improvements.

Upon completion of the external concept design review, a Science Advisory Council (SAC) was formed.  The SAC further engaged the scientific community and potential stakeholders to refine the use cases of the radar system and detail the needs and desires of the community for a next generation planetary radar system.  Membership was advertised at community meetings, and a range of subject-matter experts in planetary science, planetary defense, and space situational awareness (orbital debris) from various universities, laboratories, and institutions provided input.  The project team met multiple times with the SAC in 2024 to refine the science use cases and system requirements.

In addition to technically advancing the conceptual design of the ngRadar system, the project team was also active in the community through attendance and presentation at the Lunar and Planetary Science Conference, meetings of the NASA Small Bodies Assessment Group, and the Advanced Maui Optical and Space Surveillance Technology Conference.  Status updates were also given to the broader science community through presentations at GBO Community Zoom meetings and meetings of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American Astronomical Society, and the International Astronomical Union General Assembly.  Media presence of the project included press releases and interviews with Scientific American, Popular Science, and The Economist, as well as local and national news coverage.
